String List
[Data Types]

A RemStringList is a data type to efficiently store strings in a list. More...

Typedefs

typedef struct
_RemStringList 		RemStringList
 The RemStringList struct is an opaque data structure to represent a string list.

 Prints the content of a RemStringList to standard out.

Detailed Description

A RemStringList is a data type to efficiently store strings in a list.

Typedef Documentation

typedef struct _RemStringList RemStringList

The RemStringList struct is an opaque data structure to represent a string list.

Function Documentation

void rem_sl_append ( RemStringList *  sl,
gchar *  str 
)

Appends a string to a RemStringList.

The RemStringList takes ownership of str and frees it when rem_sl_destroy() gets called.

Parameters:
sl the RemStringList to append the string to
str the string to append

void rem_sl_append_const ( RemStringList *  sl,
const gchar *  str 
)

Appends a copy of a string to a RemStringList.

Parameters:
sl a RemStringList
str the string to append a copy of

void rem_sl_clear ( RemStringList *  sl  ) 

Removes all strings from a RemStringList.

Parameters:
sl a RemStringList

RemStringList* rem_sl_copy ( const RemStringList *  sl  ) 

Creates a copy of a RemStringList.

The copy is a real copy, i.e. the contained strings get copied too.

Parameters:
sl a RemStringList
Returns:
a copy of sl

void rem_sl_destroy ( RemStringList *  sl  ) 

Frees all of the memory used by a RemStringList (this includes all contained strings).

void rem_sl_dump ( const RemStringList *  sl  ) 

Prints the content of a RemStringList to standard out.

Parameters:
sl a RemStringList

gboolean rem_sl_equal ( const RemStringList *  sl1,
const RemStringList *  sl2 
)

Compares 2 string lists and returns TRUE if they equal.

Parameters:
sl1 a RemStringList (may be NULL)
sl2 another RemStringList (may be NULL)
Returns:
TRUE if sl1 and sl2 equal, FALSE otherwise

const gchar* rem_sl_get ( const RemStringList *  sl,
guint  index 
)

Returns the string of a RemStringList at the given index.

Do not use this function to iterate over the indivdual strings. Using rem_sl_iterator_reset() and rem_sl_iterator_next() is more efficient.

Parameters:
sl a RemStringList
index the index of the string to return
Returns:
the string at the given index or NULL if index is off the end of the RemStringList

guint rem_sl_hash ( const RemStringList *  sl  ) 

Returns a hash value of a RemStringList.

Parameters:
sl a RemStringList
Returns:
the hash value

const gchar* rem_sl_iterator_next ( const RemStringList *  sl  ) 

Iterates to the next string in a RemStringList.

Parameters:
sl a RemStringList
Returns:
the next string or NULL if there is no more string
Remarks:
This iterator does not work on string lists which contain NULL elements. This is because it is not clear whether a NULL return indicates a NULL string or the end of the list.

The const decalration of sl means the content of the string list, not the iterator state!

See also:
rem_sl_iterator_reset()

void rem_sl_iterator_reset ( const RemStringList *  sl  ) 

Resets a RemStringList its iterator.

Allways call this before iterating the list with rem_sl_iterator_next() !

Parameters:
sl a RemStringList
Remarks:
The const decalration of sl means the content of the string list, not the iterator state!

guint rem_sl_length ( const RemStringList *  sl  ) 

Returns the number of strings in a RemStringList.

Parameters:
sl a RemStringList
Returns:
the number of strings

RemStringList* rem_sl_new (  ) 

Creates a new RemStringList.

Use rem_sl_destroy() to free.
